data.text: MISSISSIPPI MARKET BULLETIN Volume 99 Number 6 Lester Spell, Jr., D.V.M., Commissioner Jackson, Mississippi March 15, 2010 2010 Jackson Garden & Patio Show By Haley Barrett Mississippi Nursery & Landscape Association, Inc The 13th Annual Jackson Garden & Patio Show is just around the corner. This year’s dates are March 19 – 21 at the Mississippi Trade Mart in Jackson. There have been plenty of changes over the years to make this show popular even with gardeners from surrounding states. For the fourth year in a row, you will be dazzled by outdoor living spaces, created by some of Mississippi’s finest landscape architects, landscape designers, and nurserymen. Here you will get ideas on how you can design your own corner of paradise. These gardens will serve as the focal point of the show. As always, we will have the experts on hand from Mississippi State University. “This is a great time to get your soil tested for free, and visit one-on-one with MSU’s plant doctor, entomologists, and horticulturists in the education area,” said Ray Bailey, past president of the Mississippi Nursery and Landscape Association, Jackson Garden & Patio Show Chairman and owner of Green Care Horticultural Services. “There will be plenty for the whole family to do while at the show. In addition to the many exhibitors, we will have the children’s activity area. Children have fallen head over heels for this,” said Bailey. In the children’s activity area, each child will be given an opportunity to learn how to plant a small flower and be given instructions for caring for it at home, along with other educational activities. The children’s area is sponsored by Ball Seed and BWI companies. For 2010, we have lined up some high profile speakers: Walt Grayson, author, WLBT TV personality and host of Look Around Missis- By Jennifer Pickett Agriculture Council of America On March 18, the Agriculture Council of America (ACA) will host two major events in the nation’s Capitol: the Mix-and-Mingle Luncheon and the National Celebration of Agriculture Dinner. The events honor National Agriculture Week and mark a nationwide effort to tell the true story of American agriculture and remind citizens that agriculture is a part of all of us. A number of producers, agricultural associations, corporations, students, and government organizations involved in agriculture are expected to participate. The annual Mix-and-Mingle Lun- sippi; Catherine Hansen Strange, co-author of Fearless Entertaining and Fearless Entertaining Flowers; Linda Askey, who has 21 years of experience with Southern Living magazine, Nellie Neal, the Garden Mama; and Erica Glasener, host of HGTV’s A Gardener’s Diary. Plus crowd favorites Lori Hitchcock, Natchez Trace Gardens; Martha Hill, Hinds Community College; National Ag Day March 20, 2010 cheon will be held at the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center, 11:30 a.m.-1:30 p.m. There is no cost to attend, but Randolph W. Graves, Madison Planting & Design Group; and Stephanie Dwyer, Stephanie Dwyer Designs will be there. For a complete list of seminars at all three shows, visit www.msnla. org. All seminars are free with admission. Admission is $8 for adults with children 10 and under are free when accompanied by an adult. This show will be open Friday 10-5, advance reservations are required. Approximately 50 student delegates from FFA, 4-H, and AFA will be in attendance, along with Outstanding Farmer of the Year honorees. The National Celebration of Agriculture Dinner will follow at the USDA Whitten Building Patio at 5:30 p.m. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack has been invited to speak. Tickets are $100 and can be purchased at www.agday.org. This is the 37th anniversary of National Ag Day (March 20, 2010), which is celebrated in classrooms and communities across the country and is part of National Ag Week (March 14-20, 2010). National Ag Day is organized by the Agriculture Council of Ameri- Saturday 9-5, and Sunday 10-4. As always, parking is free. While you are at the show, be sure to register for the fabulous door prizes donated by the exhibitors and local businesses. Watch for advertisements featuring a $5 off coupon good for $50.00 purchases at any exhibitor’s booth. The coupon is also available on the MNLA web page at www.msnla.org. Click on “To Attend” under any of the three shows listed on the home page. Of course the real stars of the show are the plants. You’ll find this year’s Mississippi Medallion winners, ferns, bedding plants, and every garden accessory you could dream about. The “Mississippi Garden and Patio Shows” and the “Mid-South Green Industry Conference,” the “Mississippi Medallion Awards Program,” and the “Certified Nursery Professional Program” are all owned by the Mississippi Nursery and Landscape Association. Unlike for-profit shows and programs, proceeds go back into the industry to support the work and programs of the organization. For more information, call MNLA at 601-919-8111 or visit www.msnla.org. Washington To Hear Amazing Story of American Agriculture ca. ACA is a nonprofit organization composed of leaders in the agricultural, food, and fiber community, dedicating its efforts to increasing the public’s awareness of agriculture’s role in modern society. The National Ag Day program encourages every American to know or appreciate the following: Understand how food and fiber products are produced, Appreciate the role agriculture plays in providing safe, abundant, and affordable products, Value the essential role of agriculture in maintaining a strong economy, and Acknowledge and consider career opportunities in the agricultural, food, and fiber industry. March 15, 2010 MISSISSIPPI MARKET BULLETIN Page 1
